author: @TheAero
text: We need LLMs to train on historic data, philosophical and god-related data. In general, feed books to models, not only the web.

author: @andyandurkar7814
text: That is an excellent explanation. You are the best. Thanks. At what point information becomes knowledge? That's the central question. Is it possible that some organization puts way too much money into building a machine that can understand math  & information? Then the question is can the AI device create new knowledge? If that is possible, then the 5+ steps described in the paper are significant, but the progress of AI could move unpredictably. What do you think?

author: @ryanhewitt9902
text: I wrote the "BULL" on a wooden sign on a fence as a narrative hypothetical for ChatGPT.  I asked about intention, outcomes and what the human character would infer.  ChatGPT passed with flying colors, both the potential dangers in detail and the reasoning behind hanging such a sign.

author: @HoriaCristescu
text: I would have included the LM "toys" - calculator, python repl, sims, search engine or external memory modules. Basically they are all simulators - of math, code, 3d or contain an extended dataset for retrieval. Probably WS6 will be a society of AI agents, this time AI interacting with AI in order to expand experience even more.

author: @bryan6aero
text: Maybe world scope six would be learning how interacting with humans influences how they in turn interact with each other or their environment.  Or is that encompassed by world scope five?

author: @jordanburgess
text: This was great explainer!  Does WS5 include AI <> AI socialisation? If not I'd offer that as WS6. You can have an awful lot of more interactions without having to rely on humans in the loop. Tho things would get very strange shortly after.

text: Very Interesting Videos and Paper. Hope will get to hear more about the progress done in WS4 and WS5 in the upcoming videos. Thanks
